article.headline: Hot springs in January, no traffic, and universal health care â the best retirement escape youâve never heard of
article.body: Money manager Matt Patsky stood at the window of his hotel on the Portuguese island of SÃ£o Miguel in March last year, looking out over the Atlantic, and thought: Iâm not sure we can retire here after all. He told his husband, âI donât know [if] we could live here. It looks like the people are crazy. There are people going in the water, swimming in the ocean. How crazy do you have to be to go swimming in the Atlantic in March?â Patsky, 56, mentioned this to a local real-estate agent later that day. The man didnât understand the issue. The water, he said, was probably no cooler than 65 degrees. How these Americans save money in retirement: They live in Spain As Boston-based Patsky adds: In New England youâre lucky if the water gets that warm in August. Itâs âone of the great selling points of the Azores,â he says. âIt is rarely below 60. It is rarely above 80. And the water temperature tends to be steady between 65 and 75 degrees.â Patsky says he and his husband, a retired businessman whoâs 66, are â80%â sure they are going to live outside the United States when they retire. They are tired especially of the politics and the racial tensions. The No. 1 thing that attracted them to the Azores â which lie barely more than twice as far from Boston as from Lisbon â wasnât the weather. It was the emigration. Portugal, they discovered, offers the all-round fastest, cheapest, easiest way to get a so-called golden visa, putting the recipient on a fast track to permanent residence and citizenship. You have to have means, but this is not purely for Rockefellers. If you want to get Portuguese residency, and a passport, you need to buy a home in the country and generally to put at least some money into fixing it up, and spend at least seven days a year in the country for the next five years. After six months, you get a residency card. After five years, a passport. The threshold prices vary, depending on the type of home you buy and where you buy it, but they start at â¬280,000 (about $310,000). As part of the deal, says Patsky, you have to buy the home with cash. You canât take out a Portuguese mortgage. But you can always raise the cash by remortgaging a U.S. home. The money thresholds are lower than in many other countries. And the seven-day requirement lets Patsky continue his job in Boston, as the CEO of socially responsible investing company Trillium, during the five years. A small but growing number of Americans are choosing to retire abroad â some because itâs cheaper; some because they have family or roots overseas; and some because of lifestyle, culture or ambience. The number of retired U.S. workers receiving Social Security checks overseas has risen by a third in 10 years, and that doesnât count all the âretirement refugeesâ who get their benefits deposited in a bank account in the U.S. Europe is by far the most popular destination by continent, with about a quarter of a million U.S. retirees, based on Social Security direct deposits. That includes nearly 13,000 in Portugal. âPortugal has been so welcoming to the LGBT community, that you are seeing a huge number of LGBT couples looking at Portugal,â reports Patsky. On their trips to the Azores, Patsky says he and his husband have been bumping into other LGBT couples from the U.S. looking at golden visas as well. On a recent trip they overheard four American women at the next table in a restaurant. It was âtwo lesbian couples from Philadelphia, looking at the âgolden visaâ and looking at property in the Azores. We ended up sitting with them with my iPad open looking at property.â You can see the islandsâ attraction. There are regular flights from various North American and European cities, Patsky says. âItâs a 4Â½-hour flight from Boston, and, because of our large Azorean population [in New England], there are actually daily flights,â he says. Pretty much everyone on the island speaks some English, which is taught in schools as a compulsory second language. âItâs like living in a Portuguese fishing village,â Patsky says of Ponta Delgada, the main city on SÃ£o Miguel. âIt has a lot of the same feel as Provincetown [on Cape Cod], in terms of being a fishing village. Itâs quaint.â The population is about 70,000. âItâs a good size, and itâs got a very vibrant economy.â Thanks to some spectacular cliffs, SÃ£o Miguel â one of the nine islands that the Azores comprise â has hosted the Red Bull World Cliff Diving World Series on several occasions, including last year. Patsky and his husband love the islandâs natural beauty. âJanuary, we were swimming, we were at the hot springs. Incredible. This really is nice weather year round. There is no traffic. There is no rush hour.â The longest distance you could drive on the island, from one point to another, would take you an hour, he says. And unlike in Boston, he adds with a laugh, you donât see snow. Both members of the couple are equally eager to retire abroad, Patsky says, in no small part to flee Americaâs rising racial tensions and poisonous politics. Last year Patskyâs husband, originally from the Philippines, was run over at a pedestrian crossing in Boston, Patsky recalls, and was left lying on the pavement with multiple fractures. When a policeman arrived at the scene, he asked the prone 65-year-old for his Social Security number to determine whether he was in the U.S. illegally, Patsky says. âMy husband and I want to make sure that our retirement is spent in a country that respects the dignity of every person,â Patsky says, âand that treats access to health care as a human right.â Portugal has a public health service, modeled after Britainâs National Health Service, which is available to all residents. The couple had started talking about an âexit planâ right after the 2016 presidential election. Their research led them to Portugal, and then to the Azores. They are hardly alone in looking at the Azores. This is starting to turn into a well-trodden exit route. âThere are hotel chains that are selling villas at exactly the price point you need to get the golden visa,â Patsky says. Theyâll even rent the villa out for you to tourists, to generate income, and say theyâll buy it back after the five years are up. Patsky says the couple wonât be moving for at least five years. Patskyâs remaining at the helm of Trillium following its takeover by Australiaâs Perpetual Ltd. PPT, +1.11%. He says one of the key appeals of Portugalâs visa program is that he can carry on working full time in the U.S. while at the same time completing the steps needed to get his Portuguese passport. Naturally, there are forms to fill out. Youâll need the usual financial and employment records. Youâll also need an FBI report to prove you have a clean rap sheet. (Pro tip from Patsky: Donât get your fingerprints done at the police station on card. Get them done electronically at the post office and apply online. It will save you weeks.) As for that major retirement headache, health care, you will need to prove you have health insurance in your home country every year during the initial five years, Patsky says. Medicare counts. And when you finally retire to the country full time? After your five-year period youâll have a Portuguese passport. And that means an EU passport. And so you can move anywhere in the EU, including those places with the most lavish, generous public health insurance. âYou can pick wherever you want to retire because itâs the EU,â Patsky says.
